$$._: Light perception at dawn plays a key role in coordinating multiple molecular processes and in entraining the plant circadian clock. The

mutant lacking the main photoreceptors, however, still shows clock entrainment, indicating that the integration of light into the morning transcriptome is not well understood. In this study, we performed a high-resolution RNA-sequencing time-series experiment, sampling every 2 min beginning at dawn. In parallel experiments, we perturbed temperature, the circadian clock, photoreceptor signaling, and chloroplast-derived light signaling. We used these data to infer a gene network that describes the gene expression dynamics after light stimulus in the morning, and then validated key edges. By sampling time points at high density, we are able to identify three light- and temperature-sensitive bursts of transcription factor activity, one of which lasts for only about 8 min. Phytochrome and cryptochrome mutants cause a delay in the transcriptional bursts at dawn, and completely remove a burst of expression in key photomorphogenesis genes (HY5 and BBX family). Our complete network is available online (

). Taken together, our results show that phytochrome and cryptochrome signaling is required for fine-tuning the dawn transcriptional response to light, but separate pathways can robustly activate much of the program in their absence.

Dawn is an important time for light entrainment and sensing environmental stimuli. This study reports a gene network that controls multiple distinct waves of gene expression in the early morning. It is shown that phytochromes and cryptochromes regulate expression of HY5, HYH, and BBX family genes in a light-dependent manner and fine-tune the dawn transcriptional response of downstream targets of HY5 and BBX family members to light.
